citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was expired pyrantel pamoate suspension dewormer (expired 07/2021) on hand.
Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate
methods to prevent and control diseases.
Medications must be administered within date to provide the appropriate response and to protect the animals from
contagious disease. The facility must ensure expired products are not used.

There was orange plastic snow fence coming up through the gravel in one of the four occupied outdoor portions of the
sheltered kennels. There was evidence of chew marks.
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in
good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from
entering.
The exposed plastic may pose a risk of injury to, entanglement of, and possible ingestion by the dogs. The licensee must
ensure to keep the housing facilities in good repair.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The licensee reported he last sanitized primary enclosures one month ago.
Used primary enclosures for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks.
Primary enclosures need to be sanitized at a minimum of every 2 weeks to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There were cobwebs and spiders present in the unoccupied kennels.
An effective program for the control of insects must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-
being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas.
The cobwebs can pose a fire risk and the spiders can cause potential injury to the animals. The licensee must ensure an
effective pest control program is in place.

The program of veterinary care did not include recommendations to prevent unmatted hair coats, toe nail trims, clean and
healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care for every dealer and
must also include preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth.
Lack of regular preventative care can lead to medical issues, such as matted haircoats, overgrown toe nails, and poor
eye, ear, skin, and dental health.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/20/2021 or the Applicant
will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next
Relicense Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it
expires.
Additional Inspectors:
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was expired pyrantel pamoate suspension dewormer (expired 07/2021) on hand. 
 
Each dealer shall establish and maintain programs of adequate veterinary care that include the use of appropriate 
methods to prevent and control diseases. 
 
Medications must be administered within date to provide the appropriate response and to protect the animals from 
contagious disease. The facility must ensure expired products are not used. 
3.1(a)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There was orange plastic snow fence coming up through the gravel in one of the four occupied outdoor portions of the 
sheltered kennels.  There was evidence of chew marks. 
 
Housing facilities for dogs must be designed and constructed so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in 
good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from 
entering.

The exposed plastic may pose a risk of injury to, entanglement of, and possible ingestion by the dogs. The licensee must 
ensure to keep the housing facilities in good repair. 
3.11(b)(2) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The licensee reported he last sanitized primary enclosures one month ago. 
 
Used primary enclosures for dogs must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. 
 
Primary enclosures need to be sanitized at a minimum of every 2 weeks to prevent an accumulation of dirt, debris, food 
waste, excreta, and other disease hazards. 
3.11(d)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There were cobwebs and spiders present in the unoccupied kennels. 
 
An effective program for the control of insects must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-
being of the animals and reduce contamination by pests in animal areas. 
 
The cobwebs can pose a fire risk and the spiders can cause potential injury to the animals. The licensee must ensure an 
effective pest control program is in place. 
3.13(a)(4) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs.

The program of veterinary care did not include recommendations to prevent unmatted hair coats, toe nail trims, clean and 
healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
The written program of veterinary care must address the requirements for adequate veterinary care for every dealer and 
must also include preventative care and treatment to ensure healthy and unmatted hair coats, properly trimmed nails, and 
clean and healthy eyes, ears, skin, and teeth. 
 
Lack of regular preventative care can lead to medical issues, such as matted haircoats, overgrown toe nails, and poor 
eye, ear, skin, and dental health. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 12/20/2021 or the Applicant 
will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next 
Relicense Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it 
expires. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
CARRIE BONGARD, ANIMAL CARE INSPECTOREnd Section
